TEXT: The applicant , PERSON , is a NORP national who was born in DATE and lives in GPE ( GPE ) . She was represented before ORG by PERSON , of ORG , who appeared on her behalf at the hearing on DATE . The respondent Government were represented at the hearing by their Agent , Mr PERSON , Deputy Attorney - General , assisted by PERSON , Deputy Attorney - General and coordinator of ORG of ORG .
The facts of the case , as submitted by the parties , may be summarised as follows .
On DATE the applicant brought an action for damages against CARDINAL private individuals and ORG ( “ the Fund ” ) in GPE after suffering a road accident . She also applied for legal aid .
On DATE the court summoned the defendants to appear .
The ORG filed pleadings in reply on DATE . CARDINAL of the other defendants filed his pleadings on DATE and also applied for legal aid .

In an order of CARDINAL DATE the court requested information from the police authorities about the financial and social circumstances of the applicant and the defendant who had applied for legal aid . ORG replied on CARDINAL DATE .

On DATE the court gave a preliminary decision ( despacho saneador ) setting out the facts that had already been established and the matters remaining to be clarified . It also awarded legal aid to the applicant and the defendant who had applied for it .

After the registry of the Caldas da Rainha District Court had realised that the applicant had not been notified either of the GPE pleadings in reply or of the preliminary decision , the court directed on DATE that those documents should be served on her .

On DATE the applicant submitted a list of the witnesses she wished to have examined . She also asked the court to order an insurance company and the PERSON medical centre to produce certain documents and requested an expert medical opinion . The court allowed her requests on DATE .
The PERSON medical centre produced the requisite documents on DATE . The insurance company did so on DATE , after the court had fined it for failing to comply with its order in good time .
In an order of CARDINAL DATE the court announced that the appointment of the experts would take place on DATE . The experts carried out the examination on DATE and submitted their report on DATE .

On DATE the court set the case down for hearing on CARDINAL DATE . However , the hearing could not take place on that date because counsel for one of the defendants was absent . It was postponed until DATE but could not take place on that date either , as ORG was occupied with the taking of evidence from witnesses in a criminal case . The hearing finally took place on DATE .
In a judgment of DATE ORG allowed the applicant ’s claims in part .
LAW of LAW enshrines the right to a “ judicial decision within a reasonable time ” .
Article CARDINAL also defines the civil liability of the ORG and its authorities and agents in the following terms :

“ The ORG and other public bodies shall be jointly and severally liable in civil law with the members of their agencies , their officials or their agents for actions or omissions in the performance of their duties , or caused by such performance , which result in violations of rights , freedoms or safeguards or in prejudice to another party . ”
Legislative Decree no . CARDINAL governs the ORG ’s non - contractual civil liability . It contains the following provisions of relevance to the instant case :
LAW

“ The ORG and other public bodies shall be liable to third parties in civil law for such breaches of their rights or of legal provisions designed to protect the interests of such parties as are caused by unlawful acts committed with negligence ( culpa ) by their agencies or officials in the performance of their duties or as a consequence thereof . ”
Article CARDINAL

“ For the purposes of this Decree , legal transactions which infringe statutory provisions and regulations or generally applicable general principles , and physical acts which infringe such provisions and principles or the technical rules and rules of general prudence that must be observed , shall be deemed unlawful . ”
Article CARDINAL

“ The obligation on the ORG and other public bodies and on members of their agencies and their officials to pay compensation shall not be contingent on the ORG use of their right of appeal against the measures that gave rise to the damage ; however , the right to compensation shall be available only if the damage is not attributable to the failure to lodge an appeal or to negligence in the conduct of proceedings after an appeal has been lodged . ”

In accordance with the case - law concerning the ORG ’s non - contractual liability , the ORG is required to pay compensation only if an unlawful act has been committed with negligence and there is a causal link between the act and the alleged damage .

Article CARDINAL of the Civil Code provides that the right to compensation is time - barred after the expiry of a period of DATE from the date on which the victim becomes , or should have become , aware of the possibility of exercising that right .

ORG decision of DATE in the case of PERSON , PERSON was for a long time the only example of the application of Legislative Decree no . DATE to the length of proceedings . Referring to the judgments of ORG in the cases of GPE v. GPE ( DATE , Series A no . CARDINAL ) , PERSON v. GPE ( DATE , Series A no . CARDINAL ) and PERSON v. GPE ( DATE , Series A no . CARDINAL ) , ORG considered that the excessive length of proceedings was to be regarded as an unlawful act meriting compensation . The main period in issue in LOC , GPE case was DATE it took for the GPE industrial tribunal to deliver a judgment that should have been given within a statutory period of DATE .

Subsequently , on DATE , ORG gave a ruling in the case of PERSON , concerning civil proceedings that had lasted DATE for CARDINAL level of jurisdiction . The appellants in that case had also lodged an application with ORG complaining of the length of those proceedings . Their application had resulted in the adoption by ORG of a resolution awarding them CARDINAL NORP escudos ( PTE ) by way of just satisfaction . ORG allowed their claims in part and ordered the ORG to pay them PTE CARDINAL in compensation , less the above - mentioned sum of PTE CARDINAL . Referring to ORG case - law , it considered , in particular , that the ORG incurred non - contractual civil liability for the non - pecuniary and pecuniary damage resulting from the unlawful and negligent administration of justice in breach of LAW CARDINAL § CARDINAL of the Convention . The judgment was published and commented on in the legal journal ORG ( no . CARDINAL , DATE ) .

ORG gave a similar decision on DATE in the case of ORG , GPE , concerning the delay with which a court ’s instructions had been carried out in enforcement proceedings . The court pointed out that failure to comply with procedural deadlines was not in itself an unlawful act but that it became unlawful if LAW was breached at the same time .

Lastly , ORG , in a judgment of DATE that was not contested by the ORG , likewise allowed a claim for damages on the basis of the ORG ’s non - contractual liability for the excessive length of proceedings concerning an objection to an enforcement measure that had already been carried out .

According to a statistical table produced by the ORG , CARDINAL actions to establish non - contractual liability on the part of the State for the excessive length of proceedings had been brought before the administrative courts . In CARDINAL of them the courts had found against the ORG , and in CARDINAL others the ORG claims had been dismissed . The proceedings are still pending in CARDINAL cases ; in CARDINAL of them , the first - instance court has found against the ORG , which has subsequently appealed to ORG .
In DATE the ORG tabled PERSON . CARDINAL in ORG , concerning the ORG ’s non - contractual civil liability and repealing Legislative Decree no . DATE .

The explanatory memorandum on the bill stated , inter alia , that “ for the first time in LANGUAGE law ” , there was a statute dealing comprehensively with the ORG ’s non - contractual liability for damage resulting from the performance of political , legislative , administrative and , “ for the first time in GPE ” , judicial duties . It pointed out that it had been “ thought helpful to incorporate into law various conclusions reached by the courts over the course of time ” .

Clauses CARDINAL of the bill governed the ORG ’s liability for damage caused in the performance of its administrative duties . Clause CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) and ( CARDINAL ) explicitly introduced the concept of “ administrative fault ” or “ official error ” .
Clause CARDINAL of the bill provided , inter alia :

“ ... the rules on liability for unlawful acts committed in the performance of administrative duties shall apply to damage caused by the unlawful administration of justice , particularly in the case of a violation of the right to a judicial decision within a reasonable time . ”
The bill lapsed as a result of the dissolution of ORG .

On DATE , however , the new ORG passed on its first reading PERSON no . CARDINAL/IX , tabled by members of ORG , which reproduced in full the explanatory memorandum to and the text of PERSON no . CARDINAL .
The bill still has to be approved on its second reading .

On DATE the Attorney - General issued a circular to all officials and members of his department . He instructed them not to challenge the administrative courts’ jurisdiction ratione materiae to deal with actions to establish non - contractual liability on the part of the ORG for the excessive length of proceedings .
By DATE Regulations on the Attorney - General ’s Department , all officials and members of the department are required to abide by the circular .
